The expectation that women adhere to mourning traditions (not dating quickly) enforces authority norms and condemns those who subvert them.
Quickly seeking a new partner is framed as socially impure or degraded behavior for women, invoking purity norms.
Women are shamed and their reputations are tarnished for dating soon after loss, whereas men face no such shame.
The frame highlights unequal standards applied to men and women, showing a clear gender-based double standard in social judgment.
By condemning women for seeking new partners, the frame implicitly endorses restricting women’s freedom of choice while allowing men unrestricted liberty.
The moral judgment against women rapidly forming new relationships invokes purity norms, treating women who do so as ‘impure’ or morally degraded.
The condemnation imposes shame on women for their personal decisions, leveraging social stigma to police their behavior and reputation.
